newsitem.title: EGYPT: Next Egyptian privatisation at P/E of about eight. [CORRECTED 23/10 01:10 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Next Egyptian privatisation at P/E of about eight. [CORRECTED 23/10 01:10 GMT]

text.p: Shares in Egyptian state company General Silos and Storage will go on sale for two days from October 28 at a price/earnings ratio of about eight compared to a market average of nearly nine, according to details made available on Tuesday.
The privatisation will be the first for about a month and mark the start of an accelerated programme in which the state expects to sell 91 companies by the middle of 1998.
The state's Holding Company for Rice and Flour Mills, which owns General Silos and Storage, will offer four million of the 10 million shares in the company at 37 pounds ($10.90) a share.

Two million shares are available to individuals, one million to financial institutions and mutual funds and one million to the Employee Shareholder Association, which buys on behalf of workers, a holding company official said.

The state does not intend to sell more than 40 percent, regardless of demand, because General Silos works in what the state considers a strategic sector -- the storage and transport of wheat for subsidised bread.

The official, financial department head Kamel el-Qumus Mikhail, told Reuters the company made net profits of 48.3 million pounds ($14.2 million) (corrects dollar conversion from "$142,000") in the financial year 1995/6, compared with 40.489 million in 1994/5 and 32.992 million in 1993/4. The years end on June 30.

The company is forecasting net profits of 53.485 million pounds (corrects from 43.485 million pounds) in the current year and 61 million in 1997/8. For last year it will pay a dividend of at least 3.35 pounds, he said.
The company owns five grain silos with a total capacity of 529,000 tonnes and a fleet of 121 trucks. The state has valued its assets at more than 325 million pounds.
